results.title: 10 Reasons Why Squirrels are the Music Nuts of the Animal Kingdom | The Capitol Theatre
results.description: Words by: Olivia Viana Today we're celebrating all of the bushy-tailed little nut-gatherers of the world! It's no secret that we love squirrels over here at The Cap. Not only are they our loyal mascot, they're also funny, wild, and not afraid to be

extra_snippets: Just like music fans, squirrels are everywhere, and connections can happen in unexpected ways. These spunky critters spend their day outsmarting hungry hawks, goofing around, and searching for food. Just like a hardcore music fans seaching for a ticket to a sold out show, if a squirrel wants something, it goes out and gets it, and doesn't let anyone get in their way.

Much like we music fans do with our precious concert tickets merch, and posters, squirrels are incredibly inventive when it comes to keeping their food stashes safe. You could call them hoarders, but only to a healthy extent.

Squirrels are loyal to their buddies and keep an eye out for each other, especially when times get tough. If it seems like something's going wrong, or, better yet, there's some delicious acorns nearby, they let out a loud whistle to give their friends the heads up. Ever go the extra mile to let a concert buddy know when a show's about to sell out? Kind of like that. Much like we music fans do with our precious concert tickets merch, and posters, squirrels are incredibly inventive when it comes to keeping their food stashes safe.

It's no secret that we love squirrels over here at The Cap. Not only are they our loyal mascot, they're also funny, wild, and not afraid to be themselves. Truth be told, they're a lot like us and our fellow music fans. To celebrate Squirrel Appreciation Day, here's a look at why squirrels are just like us... music nuts!

results.description: The Outside Story Squirrel talk: what does that noise mean? by Laurie D. Morrissey Even if you’ve never ventured further into the forest than an urban park or a college campus, you’re probably familiar with Sciurus carolinensis, the eastern gray squirrel.

meta_url.path: › squirrel-talk-what-does-that-noise-mean

extra_snippets: If you’re not big or scary-looking, one way to protect yourself is to make a lot of noise. Squirrels have it covered. “They have three acoustically distinct alarm calls: kuks, quaas, and moans,” Mr. McRae said. “The most common sound by far is the kuk, which sounds like the bark of a very, very small dog.

It is usually repeated very rapidly for a few seconds, before slowing down.” · The quaa, on the other hand, sounds like a raspy meow — like the noise I heard near my house. “Kuks and quaas are used to scare off predators and to warn other squirrels. Both are noisy, scratchy sounds with no clear note or tone,” Mr.

In a mostly coniferous forest, the squirrel you hear chattering is likely a red squirrel, which feeds mainly on the seeds of evergreen trees. Gray squirrels are more common in mature hardwood forests or mixed deciduous-conifer forests, where they find tree nuts, holes for nesting, and a dense canopy to hide in. Once I figured out that a gray squirrel produced the raspy meow I heard as I walked down a dirt road near my house, I began to wonder about the various sounds made by this species.

Sometimes described as sounding like a stifled sneeze, this noise is used as a contact sound between mother and kits, and by males when courting females, according to Mr. McRae. There is much still to learn about squirrel communication, including whether there are regional variations, as is the case with some songbirds. “Some bird species sing higher pitched songs in cities than in rural areas. It seems to help them to be heard over background noise,” said Mr. McRae. “Do city squirrels do something similar?

results.title: [10] Sounds That Scare Squirrels Away
results.description: Outdoor speakers playing loud music can aid in keeping squirrels at a safe distance. According to one study, playing loud music caused squirrels to run an average of more than 22 feet away—an increase of more than 9 feet from the group in which music was not playing.

meta_url.path: › home  › [10] sounds that scare squirrels away

items.question: Will A Radio Sound Keep Squirrels Away?
items.answer:
Yes, Radio Sound Keeps Squirrels Away. Radios set to dialogue could deceive squirrels into believing that people are around.
Your trash cans or chicken coop may attract squirrels, but the sound of the radio can scare them away. Consider often changing the channel, relocating the radio to various areas, and occasionally tweaking the volume to keep the squirrels guessing.
items.title: [10] Sounds That Scare Squirrels Away

meta_url.path: › home  › [10] sounds that scare squirrels away

items.question: What Sound Frequency Do Squirrels Hate?
items.answer:
There is no clear answer because various squirrels appear to have varied aversion thresholds. In general, higher-pitched frequencies appear to work better than lower-pitched ones to repel squirrels. This makes sense because higher-pitched sounds make animals more prone to become irritated or uncomfortable.
The normal frequencies that irritate squirrel ears are between 20,000 and 25,000 Hz, with 25,000 being the typical threshold at which irritation becomes severe.
items.title: [10] Sounds That Scare Squirrels Away

meta_url.path: › home  › [10] sounds that scare squirrels away

items.question: Are Squirrel-Repellent Sound Devices Short-Term Effective?
items.answer:
Sound repellents may be effective in the short term for gardening purposes, such as keeping squirrels away from a newly planted bed until the seedlings become strong enough to withstand harm.
Still, they are unlikely to offer a permanent solution. However, sometimes squirrels tend to adapt to these sounds. They become accustomed to not being afraid of anything when they continually hear a menacing sound without any risk.
items.title: [10] Sounds That Scare Squirrels Away

meta_url.path: › home  › [10] sounds that scare squirrels away

items.question: How Do Squirrel-Repellent Sound Devices Work?
items.answer:
1- These gadgets produce high-frequency sound waves exceeding the hearing range of humans but at a volume that rodents like squirrels, rats, and others can hear and, initially, be bothered by. 
2- Most of these gadgets are electrically driven and can either be plugged into a socket or run on batteries. 
3- Additionally, it should be noted that because the US Environmental Protection Agency does not register these kinds of devices, the businesses that sell them are not required to give evidence that they function as advertised.

meta_url.path: › what-sounds-and-noises-do-squirrels-make-and-what-do-they-mean

extra_snippets: Squirrels are pretty noisy critters that possess quite the vocal range! Common squirrel noises sound like barks, screams and chirps and the sounds mean different things. Let’s take a look, and listen, at the most common squirrel sounds as well as a few you may not have heard before!

Moans are quiet calls that sound like a chirp. The Moan is used when the squirrel believes the predator has left but isn’t really sure. Because the squirrel is not positive of the predator’s location it uses this quieter call so it does not give the predator any clues.

It has also been noted that Eastern gray squirrels communicate through tail flicks. In case of an aerial threat (like from a hawk, eagle or owl), the squirrels elicit a moan. On encountering a terrestrial threat, they respond with a tail flick. Kuks and Quaas, on the other hand, do not carry information regarding the type of threat and seem to be general alarm calls.

However, in the case of dogs and coyotes, they will simply stand outside the burrow’s entrance but not retreat inside. Here is a wonderful video describing the research which has been done on the amazingly complex Prairie dog language. North American red squirrels respond to predators through three kinds of alarm calls. These are seets, barks, and seet-barks. Seets are high-frequency sounds of low amplitude. Barks are loud alarm calls that have broad overtones. Seet-barks are an intermediate of the other two sounds. They start like seets, add some harmonics, and end with a bark.

Pets and Animals | Northern California dog owners warned by state wildlife officials to keep their canines away from raw fish Squirrels have other conversations, too. Young squirrels make a muffled sort of call when asking mom for food; the male uses a similar call when chasing his intended sweetheart up tree and down, telling her he’s not dangerous, he just seeks a little love.

Although their calls sometimes sound like they’re scolding us — or the cat — most of them are alarm signals given both to warn off a predator and to warn other squirrels of danger. In some cases, the squirrel is telling a predator that it sees it, is well aware that it is being stalked, and so there will be no element of surprise. At other times, the squirrel sends out an alarm, telling other squirrels that something bad is going on.

extra_snippets: Birds aren't the only animals calling from trees. You may have been scolded by a squirrel without even recognizing it. Chattering noises might sound like some kind of bird, and squirrels can make a screeching noise similar to a bluejay. You might hear an alarm call, raised because of the presence of an intruder -- ...

Squirrels are on the lookout for threats from above and below. When they spot a predator like a cat or a hawk, they'll make a series of barking alarm calls. Dr. Robert S. Lishak recorded squirrels on the Auburn University campus and categorized their calls. He describes a low-intensity "buzz" of quick notes emitted from the nostrils.

Richard W. Thorington, Jr. of the Smithsonian Department of Vertebrate Zoology describes sounds made by baby squirrels, varying by their age. They use these calls to summon their mothers. They can squeak by three days of age, growl by three weeks and by four weeks they can emit short screams. Thorington and Lishak describe a "muk-muk" call as a quiet sound a little bit like a puffing noise. You're not likely to hear it coming from a nest high in a tree, but baby squirrels use it to softly call their mother to give them a feeding.

You're not likely to hear it coming from a nest high in a tree, but baby squirrels use it to softly call their mother to give them a feeding. Lishak and Thorington also describe the muk-muk call as used by the male squirrel to signal interest in mating with a female. It's an imitation of a baby squirrel, intended to signal that the male squirrel is not presenting a threat to the female.
